title: Monday, 16th July, 2018

Swedish Chef What’s the collective noun for a group of HL users? A platform?

Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 1,976, down 81 (-3.94%), High: 2,030, Low: 1,965, Volume: 726.31k
ralph ftse is strong and stable that's why

So ...... this is on the FCA looking at killing exit fees.

Excel Developer Holy Article 50 Batman!
BE11:12am

Investment platform review interim report

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Final conclusions due early 2019,

BornCynic Morning - BE, your not talking Musk looks a lot like the rest of the internet.
Excel Developer SP500 only 3% from peak.
alewis2005 Morning all
Pharma @Lemmy, there is a majority for "In", but they have a well-founded fear for their jobs, so they are going to pretend to vote for "out".On this parliamentary opinion is a good proxy for multinational business opinion, so FTSE is sanguine.
alewis2005 just going to complain here that Tr*mp delayed my Stansted->Glasgow flight on friday evening by deciding to take the same route
BE11:14am

Hargreaves does charge transfer/exit fees, but does not charge clients for holding cash in their accounts ...

Tom Dalgleish he has the personality of a coder
BornCynic How about talking neil Collins - his column is telling it like it is at the moment.
Excel Developer @Tom Dalgleish : steady on
Lemmy Pharma: I can see the majority for in but Labour will be whipped to vote against this so this majority may not exist in the divisions
BE11:15am

... and the impact in terms of numbers looks to be pretty small from exit fees disappearing. About 1% I think.

Shrink But you can't have interest with them if you hold cash.....which means they make money that way..
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:16am

The FCA found a “mixed picture”, and noted the market appears to be working well in many respects, and customer satisfaction is currently high. The FCA found that consumers who pay more for their platform tend to get greater functionality on average, and the FCA did not observe widespread instances of consumers paying more for no good reason. We believe this is the key point, the FCA not proposing any pricing action, and highlighting that the more expensive platforms like Hargreaves do offer greater functionality. In our view, it is the quality and ease of use of the Hargreaves platform that results in its high customer satisfaction driving its market share and growth, and hence its PE rating (of 34x, towards the top end of its historical range), and we reiterate our Overweight rating with price target of 2100p.

BE11:17am

The FCA did find five areas for concern 1. switching between platforms can be difficult 2. shopping around can be difficult 3. The risks and expected returns of model portfolios with similar risk labels are unclear, 4. Consumers may be missing out by holding too much cash and 5. So-called “orphan clients” who were previously advised but no longer have any r’ship with a financial adviser face higher charges and lower service.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Importantly, on potential remedies, the FCA are NOT proposing additional costs and charges disclosure at this stage, as the implementation of the new MiFiD II rules is likely to improve disclosure and comparability. The FCA is proposing abolishing exit fees, BUT no other pricing action, and did highlight that customers who pay more tend to get more. Furthermore, while the FCA did note one player had a 40% market share in the D2C market, they also noted that platform financial performance does not suggest widespread competition concerns in the market.

BE11:17am

We do not find sustained excess profitability on aggregate in this market, and many platforms are loss making. We highlight that in our view, the impact on Hargreaves Lansdown is minimal. While they may be on the higher end of spectrum in terms of pricing, the quality and use the platform offers results in high consumer satisfaction driving its market share and growth. Revenues earned from exit fees are immaterial and hence any ban on such charges would not materially impact its bottom line. Being the largest player in the D2C platform market,

BE11:17am

Hargreaves is able to negotiate good fund discounts as we have previously written about, but this is unsurprising and natural for a market leader. It benefits the end customer and has limited impact on competition among asset managers. Hargreaves has also been innovative in its cash offerings which include Simple Invest and Active Savings and have provided relatively good disclosures regarding charges on cash holdings.

Pharma @Lemmy, don't believe there's a quorum in the Commons, so with lots of abstentions* it could end up being very random.*Labour whips not being the most effective at the moment
BornCynic If PM were here I would ask him about Allied Minds - feel free to say no news, no change in volume BE.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

And Citi.

Lemmy Pharma: indeed, so risk of political uncertainty looks rather high to me
BE11:18am

Any reduction in exit fees would likely only have a small impact on
earnings for platforms such as Hargreaves Lansdown. But increased ease of transfer between platforms could lead to a lower retention rate (i.e. lower net flows). This has been stable, and high, at around 93% for many years. More transparency of pricing could also bring the relatively higher costs of platforms such as HL into consumer focus. Any move that aligns the “best” fund prices across platforms would likely lead to increased fee margin pressure for UK Retail Fund managers, in our view. We would highlight risk to Jupiter Fund Management.

Grouchmonkey Ohayo gozaimasu
rw42 Feels like we need either another GE or referendum, with each party being clear on whether they're for or against the brexit settlement when it's agreed!
Shrink I'd be happy if they just abolish the exit fees.
Sails yes steady on @Tom
Excel Developer @Shrink: sure, but where would you exit to?
Grouchmonkey @ALewis you should sue him
rw42 @Excel - i've got normal, ISA + SIPP with them, and only using the SIPP - i'd move the ~50 quid in each of the others to the SIPP if there was no exit fee, but no point when i'd be losing most of it..
Jupiter Fund Management PLC (JUP:LSE): Last: 439.00, down 0.6 (-0.14%), High: 440.70, Low: 437.50, Volume: 249.46k
chopper bear may to resign by end of sept at 11/2 ? got to be worth a tenner
Pharma @Lemmy, you are questioning why markets aren't behaving entirely rationally. I would point you to history and shrug.
Mr Diamond any references to platform changes that have been totally mishandled ref. Barclays Smart Investor
11:22 am
BE11:22am

So, that's Hargreaves. Move feels knee jerk on a consultation about not very much money, but valuation leaves little room for any kind of uncertainty I guess.

undefined
Lemmy Fair enough Pharma, parts of the FTSE could gain from the mess eg if GBP tanks etc, but the exposed sectors don't seem affected so much either
cracklenpop @ShrinkYour right - think HL make £30-£40m that way every year.
Grouchmonkey Indivior? Seems a massive overreaction to just an extension of the interim injunction
BE11:24am

(@BornCynic: I know nothing whatsoever about Allied Minds and have never said a single thing about Allied Minds here that was even mildly positive. But it's nice that you mention it every day apropos of nothing. Really good for the mood of the room.)

patatbat Lol @ indv if you wanted to explain volatility to someone that stock is textbook
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Indivior? Sure.

Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 365.90, up 74.7 (+25.65%), High: 391.40, Low: 355.40, Volume: 3.41m
cheeckychappy @BE - noticed u gave the old AstraZeneca bid rumour another airing in your market report - punchy!

Interim injunction awarded late on Friday to keep generic suboxone off the market for a while .....

Excel Developer @Lemmy: we need a 2nd referendum to break the parliamentary deadlock, 3 proposals, (i) WTO (ii) Remain (iii) May's compromise with transferable vote so winner gets 50% mandate. https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-44840154
Shrink @cracklenpop: It just makes one feels ripped off, that's all.
Pharma Presumably the key question is how much HL makes from people *not* moving their money because of exit fees.
Shrink @Pharma: Quite.
11:25 am

........ probably until a patent case resolves, but Dr Reddy's can also appeal.

...... on one hand, you can argue that generic suboxone is like generic Advair for GSK .....

Pharma @Excel, why have two options that effectively mean remain?(yes, I know why - who gets to write the question is the main issue)
BE11:27am

...... we all know it's coming so revenue while it doesn't should be treated as exceptional

Excel Developer May's compromise does not mean remain. Only 20% of the economy subject to the common rulebook, so 80% is free.
Plato the Cook @Pharma, because people like me would vote: 1. Stay in, 2. Get out, with a pointless fudge in the middle as a non-starter
11:28 am
BE11:28am

.... but also, Indivior's making a mess of the Sublocade launch

BornCynic Apologies BE - it was not my intention to get up your nose. I shall remain quiet about it - given past experience I just thought that you might have some information in your inbox or from PM. The reason for asking was that I was thinking of buying.
BE11:29am

The longer it can stop generics coming and kicking the chair from below Suboxone, the longer it has to make Sublocade a success

BE11:29am

(@Borncynic: apologies also. I don't function well above 17 degrees.)

BornCynic BE - no problem.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Numis incoming.

BE11:30am

The shares will receive a boost today, and we await further detail on pricing trends in generic tablets, film share, the scale of Dr Reddy’s initial shipment and most importantly on the uptake of the monthly, Sublocade in a changing market-place at interims on 25 July. From a cash flow perspective, Indivior should benefit from at least an additional three months of Suboxone Film (c.$50m), which is not material to our SOTP valuation. We move back to ADD on valuation grounds but with more information needed on the ramp of Sublocade to move back to a higher-conviction rating.

BE11:31am

This is Paul Cuddon, who's good. You'll remember his stuff on GW Pharma, which was really excellent and wrong by about 500%.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Too few patients currently access Suboxone Film, and we continue to believe that broader access to Suboxone Film would serve to increase the addressable market for Sublocade (ie non-compliant daily users, diverters and abusers). A settlement with Dr Reddy’s would be our favoured outcome, rather than repeated, costly and binary litigation decisions, in our view.

Pharma @Excel I think your numbers are wrong. The 20% refers to exports, but the rules will apply across the internal economy just as they do now.Also, do you think we will end up diverging sets of employment law etc. depending on whether or not you make stuff.
Lemmy Plato the Cook: agreed, a vote has to be on something very clear cut, not grey. Which means the UK could be stuck in a pickle
Excel Developer @Pharma: no - it's just traded goods to stop lorries stacking up on Brexit day. Services completely free.
BE11:34am

A thing to remember here, BTW, is that Camurus has a regulatory ruling due December on its Sublocade-alike ......

BE11:35am

...................... so while the window to establish Sublocade as the leader is lengthened, there are still a few hurdles pre the patent resolution.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Jefferies:

BE11:36am

While the PI ruling could prevent DRRD from launching until the outcome of the '305 patent case (mid 2020), Alvogen could still launch near term. In our base case we assume Alvogen launches mid-2019 and DRRD and Mylan launch mid 2020, while Teva is enjoined from launching until 2024. That said, we recognise there is upside to this case as the recent PI makes a settlement with Alvogen more likely, while the court specifically determined that it is likely that DRRD infringes the ‘305 patent, which could mean DRRD is enjoined from launching until 2022.

Plato the Cook @Lemmy I look at it this way: if we weren't in the EU, we might have a referendum on whether to join or not, but never on whether to join a bit of it. But enough - my blood pressure is already rising
cracklenpop @Excel Developer80% of economy (services) 'is free' - for now... This is just the start of negotiations, EU won't wear 'cherry-picking'.
CS1 After we exit, there is no chance the EU will allow us to influence changes to the rule book
BE11:37am

While Sublocade uptake is below expectations, we note initial patient and physician feedback has been positive, with the slow uptake due to friction in the new reimbursement and distribution model. We continue to be confident in the demand for this treatment and maintain $2bn peak sales forecast albeit delayed 2 years to 2026.

Pharma @Excel. From what I have read that's not correct. If it was, it would be a free trade deal. This is "a" customs union, where rules are constant across both areas.The rules are those set by the EU, and enforced by the ECJ. Under May's scheme the UK will not, for example, be able to make the sale of incandescent bulbs legal again.
11:37 am

Was it Sunday Times? I only read the Guardian lift of it... Apologies.

https://www.thetim...e-fright-pk0zl52wk

cracklenpop @BESunday Times lead yesterday
BE11:44am

One of the leading insurers, Euler Hermes, is understood to have reduced cover dramatically for suppliers to Debenhams, while rivals Atradius and Coface are said to have refused to cover new shipments in recent days.

Tax Realist Surely someone should be asking the insurance companies rather than Debs?
Pseudonym @Excel Courts shouldn't make laws, however in effect that's the way the ECJ will function with respect to the UK as the UK won't write the laws.
BE11:46am

.... I should pay more attention to the Sundays. But, hey, it was hot. Here's the denial anyway: https://www.ft.com...-b18d-0181731a0340

11:47 am
BE11:47am

A spokesperson said:

Debenhams has a healthy balance sheet and cash position. All the credit insurers continue to provide cover to our suppliers and we maintain a constructive relationship with them. It is well-documented that market conditions are challenging, but Debenhams continues to be profitable, has a clear strategy in place and is taking decisive actions to strengthen the business‎.

Excel Developer @Pseudonym: I disagree, I like judicial activism. Have you actually watched Parliament? They're rubbish, they do not deliberate (verb) . They simply line up to score points against each other. Parliament is pathetic IMHO.
Pharma Nothing in that statement is inconsistent with what the Sunday Times wrote.
alewis2005 Debs was in todays CityAM as well about suppliers insurance
BE11:48am

...... and this long pause is me looking for some analysis of a story I didn't read that closely.

BE11:49am

Let's try UBS.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

We are ceasing coverage of Debenhams with immediate effect, due to a reallocation of resources.

Tom Dalgleish Very astute Pharma
cracklenpop @PharmaAlways the canary in the mine when TCI's withdraw cover.
BE11:49am

Oh.

Tom Dalgleish all weasel words
Pharma @cracklenpop, which they haven't denied. They just haven't *completely* removed cover.
BE11:50am

Aha -- Liberum. That'll do.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Over the weekend, The Times newspaper reported that credit insurers are tightening their terms on suppliers to Debenhams. It is claimed that a leading insurer, Euler Hermes, has dramatically reduced the cover it is prepared to offer, while others insurers (Atradius and Coface) are believed to have refused cover on recent shipments. A follow up article this morning, again in The Times, commented that Debenhams insists it has a “healthy” cash position.

Tax Realist They are continuing cover already written but not new cover?
BE11:51am

We have not managed to speak with company at this stage, but note that instances of credit insurance withdrawals or reductions have been prevalent this year (House of Fraser, New Look, and Poundland). If the news flow is true then it will heap more pressure on Debenhams, which has seen EPS downgrades of 54% since the beginning of the year.

Pseudonym @Excel If laws are made by an appointed judiciary then we have no democracy. However I do agree that we seem to have hit a pretty low standard.
BE11:52am

The FY1 dividend yield is currently 7.5%, but it is uncovered by free cash flow (-0.4x).

Fox What is Mike Ashley truly up to? 29.7% stake?
11:52 am
BE11:52am

We continue to forecast net debt of £297m at the year-end { 1.8x net debt/EBITDA }.

BornCynic Debenhams gave the best exchange rate on foreign currency a few days ago - which surprised me.
BE11:53am

The company also ranks poorly on our quality metrics screen, with operational gearing of more than 20x and fixed charge cover (on an EBIT basis) of 1.1x. In order to protect the balance sheet the company mentioned it has a number of measures it will be taking including (i) lower capex (we forecast c.£150m in FY18E dropping to c.£100m in FY19E); (ii) costs savings programmes; (iii) and the potential sale of international operational (including Magasin du Nord) which contributes 20% of EBITDA and is currently the only part of the business that is growing. As a mid-market department store, Debenhams is being squeezed by more premium players, specialists and online. Progress is being made under the ‘Destination, Digital, Different’ pillars of the new strategy, but we have yet to see this feed into the group’s financial performance and visibility remains low. Turning 13 million sq. ft. into ‘destination’ space is tough and material closures/right-sizing will take time. Structural challenges persist and we see the company as a value trap.

Grouchmonkey @borncynic trying to generate some quick cash flow?
undefined
Pharma @BornCynic, a cynic might wonder if they were using currency pre-orders as a form of trade finance

How on earth is it not midday yet?

BornCynic So how hot is it in London today BE?
Tom Dalgleish DEB is more evidence of a precipice looming

(@BornCynic: I dream of rain.)

alewis2005 @BE you should have gone to Glasgow with me over the weekend. Yesterday was cold and wet
BornCynic BE - you mean you dream of Scotland :)
BE11:57am

There's a bunch of sellside around, most of which is summarised here: https://www.ft.com...-b18d-0181731a0340

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Of those, the Micro Focus one from Credit Suisse is probably most interesting.

alewis2005 oh @Pseudonym where were you sailing at the weekend?
Soundbuy Micro Focus - off 4.5%..........
BE11:58am

Two good pars ......

Excel Developer Buy the SP500, it has plunge protection team standing by.
Pseudonym Irish Sea, it went pretty badly lack of wind resulted in a much shortened course.
BE11:58am

Micro Focus pre-announced results so there were no major surprises. Overall, revenues were down 6.9% with core declines of 8.7%, partially offset by 16% growth in SUSE. The one surprise was higher
restructuring charges to improve the FAST IT platform. Management now
expects restructuring of $960m vs $750m previously. It's a small delta in the context of the EV, but is a reminder of our long-standing argument regarding the mis-match between profits and cash flow.

alewis2005 we had similar problems on the Clyde
11:59 am
BE11:59am

SUSE changes the investment case: We think selling SUSE changes the
investment case. Specifically, without SUSE, it is difficult to argue that
revenue stability is plausible. Based on the 3 years prior to the HP
transaction, the track record ex-SUSE is closer to -5% pa. And HP was
described as broadly similar. Management has consistently said that past
trends continue until you do something to change momentum. However, we see no initiatives that suggest change is underway, making -5% revenue growth the most sensible base case scenario, in our view.

alewis2005 not enough wind, too much rain!
Pharma DEB is evidence of really badly run shops. Not sure if it's possible to extrapolate , except to other really badly run shops.
Alchemy30 Good for me, was out waterskiing on the South East Coast
BE11:59am

This is the eternal story of the rollup.

Sails e.g. M&S is a badly-run shop
Blank canvas thanks for everything today
BE12:01pm

Withering core business and massive exceptionals year after year. When it stops moving you end up with an unravelling and it's discovered that there's not a lot of cash at the core.

Tom Dalgleish but DEB is a credit event
Tom Dalgleish approaching mid-terms has to be precarious generally
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

You can, however, make a case for rollups flogging off everything they bought, assuming their quasi-PE ownership hasn't damaged it too much.

BE12:02pm

That's UBS's argument.

Soundbuy Greggs - hit a year low earlier this morning........
BE12:03pm

After selling SUSE, it is hard to see MCRO delivering sustainable long-term growth, although with easy licence comparatives, periods of brief growth should be possible. However, MCRO generates lots of cash and sees many consolidation opportunities still. Once internal IT issues are resolved, it will also have a state-of-the-art platform to onboard new assets. While 'elephant' deals such as HPE Software cannot be completely ruled out, we think MCRO will prefer to bolt-on multiple smaller businesses. Management's reputation has taken a knock over the poor integration of HPE Software, but the shares today look relatively inexpensive: Broadcom is buying competitor CA for a CY19E 12.8x EV/EBITDA, while MCRO is trading at an ex-SUSE CY19E core EV/EBITDA of 6.6x.

Grouchmonkey @Tom @Pharma it's like the Carillion story - lousy sector, particularly lousy/slightly unlucky player in it. does not look promising, to me.
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

While we acknowledge competition is a meaningful headwind, the fact that licences fell in N America (29%) by much more than in EMEA (7%) or APJ (10%) suggests to us that sales execution/integration issues are the primary drag. Guidance implies a 4-10% decline in the current period (UBSe: -8%) and we are at -4% in FY19 (was -1%), having assumed the sale of SUSE goes through at the end of the year. We assume a $1.8n return of value in mid-19 and in total with dividends we estimate investors could receive $2.5bn over the next 18 months – almost a third of today's market cap. Our FY18E EPS falls 6% on higher interest costs, while SUSE and the capital return impact FY 19E and FY 20E.

BE12:04pm

Buy up to 1950p, they say.

Grouchmonkey Whereas Greggs is well managed and the High Street woe is overdone. Just because people aren't shopping does not mean they are not wandering up and down scarfing Greggs. Though not in this weather, obviously.
undefined
BornCynic @Pharma - your comment about Pfizer only hiring Chinese researchers. I forgot to tell you why Pfizer based the animal testing unit in France - the French are not too hot on animal rights (foie gras etc.). A recent program showed Chinese doing genetic experiments on animals - when interviewed they did not seem worried about any ethical considerations.So maybe Pfizer are looking to China for that reason? Different ethics?
cracklenpop @Born CynicIn Spain, ze animals have no rights.
Excel Developer @BornCynic: it's because the Chinese don't have a rights based political culture (backed up by courts).
anonymous254 @BornCynic, also, the thesis has been that if hire local, it eases passage on regulatory process. In theory that is.
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Will that do?

Pharma @BornCynic, possible, and I imagine lab/chemical safety rules are not so strict, nor so strictly enforced (same is true for US vs. europe, but to a lesser extent. e.g. they still use benzene in US labs).
alewis2005 tyvm @BE
BE12:07pm

We made it to midday. I only briefly let slip that I didn't bother reading the Sunday Times over the weekend, but I don't think anyone noticed.

Grouchmonkey Thanks for solo effort BE - appreciated
BE12:08pm

Thanks for sticking around.

Excel Developer S&P 500 to mount assault on previous high. Only 3% to go. Cheers bye,
12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Back tomorrow.

Soundbuy You got away with it defo...........
BE12:08pm

Afternoon all.

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
